reasoning: The critique targets an alleged political function/motive (“elite rent-seeking,” “technocratic moral optimizers”) rather than the essay’s core substantive claim that near-best futures are a narrow target due to moral/value fragility and fussiness of plausible value functions. Since the position does not centrally argue for transferring power from democracy to a technocratic caste, refuting the motive story would only weakly affect the position (low centrality). The critique provides little object-level engagement with the essay’s premises (e.g., multiplicative fragility, population ethics/diversity/digital welfare, boundedness/linearity arguments), so it barely weakens what it attacks (low strength). Several characterizations are dubious or overstated (e.g., portraying the authors as calling a “happy, free, abundant” future a moral catastrophe merely for missing a 99.99th-percentile target; the essay’s thresholds and intent are more nuanced), and the principal-agent/“stealing surplus” claim is speculative (low correctness). It is nonetheless understandable and focused (high clarity, single issue), with limited pure filler beyond the rhetorical framing (low-to-moderate dead weight).
title: Rejecting common-sense utopia enables elite capture of moral authority
